msIdentifier.collection: Historical Society of Pennsylvania cartoons and caricatures collection

history.acquisition: This is an artificial collection created over time by HSP staff mostly through donations and purchases of individual prints. It also incorporates previously uncataloged materials collected by the Balch Institute for Ethnic Studies. Some of the 20th century cartoons and drawings were removed from the J. Hampton Moore papers (Collection 1541).

analytic.title: If--The Inaugural Dinner at the White House

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.
This xml file uses unique entity identifiers, media file identifiers, and collection identifiers in HSP's Digital Library, available at http://digitallibrary.hsp.org.

div.p: William Randolph Hearst owned the New York Journal and the San Francisco Examiner and in 1904 campaigned to become the democratic nominee. He lost the nomination to Alton B. Parker in July 1904. In the cartoon, William Randolph Hearst, dressed in formal attire, gives a toast to a cast of comic cartoon characters who are seated at a large table. Most of the comic characters appeared in Hearst's newspapers.

Next to Hearst there is a waiter carrying a tray with drinks and a dinosaur who is eating a portrait of Theodore Roosevelt. The comic cartoon character, Foxy Grandpa, is seated to Hearst's left. On the window sill, characters from the Little Tigers comic strip play musical instruments. Hanz from the comic strip Katzenjammer Kids, balances a champagne bottle on his nose. His brother Fritz sprays champagne into der Captain's face. Mamma, the woman seated across from Fritz, looks stern and points her finger in disapproval. Alphose and Gaston, in the lower right corner of the image, bow to each other.
THE INAUGURAL DINNER AT THE WHITE HOUSE.

William Randolph Hearst, owner of the New York Journal and San Francisco Examiner, gives a toast to a cast of popular comic strip characters published in his newspapers. In the 1904 presidential election, he sought the democratic party nomination, but lost to Alton B. Parker.
Cartoon characters from Jimmy Swinnerton's Little Tigers comic strip play musical instruments. Little Tigers was published in Hearst's San Francisco Examiner.

Happy Hooligan wears tattered clothing, holds a champagne bottle and raises his glass. Happy Hooligan and the policeman standing next to him were drawn by the cartoonist Frederick Burr Opper. Both characters were featured in the strip Happy Hooligan which debuted in 1900 in Hearst's newspapers.

Alphonse and Gaston was a comic strip by the cartoonist Frederick Burr Opper. It debuted in the New York Journal in 1901 and featured two Frenchmen who are so polite that they never managed to get anywhere or accomplish anything. They each bow to each other and insist that the other go first: "After you, Alphonse"; "No, you first, my dear Gaston." In the political cartoon, Gaston, the tall and slender man and his short friend Alphonse bow to each other. Most likely they each insist that the other take a seat.

The Katzenjammer Kids was a Sunday comic strip published in the New York Journal and featured two naughty children named Hans and Fritz. In the political cartoon, Hans balances a champagne bottle on his nose while his brother Fritz sprays champagne into der Captain's face. Their mother "mamma" looks disapprovingly and points her finger at them. The character seated next to mamma is most likely the Inspector from The Katzenjammer Kids. The man seated next to the Inspector is Uncle Heinie, also from The Katzenjammer Kids.

Mr. Jack was an early 20th century comic strip by cartoonist James Swinnerton and featured a bachelor tiger. The character of Mr. Jack first appeared in Swinnerton's Little Tigers. In the political cartoon, Mr. Jack wears a top hat and bow tie and raises his glass.
Foxy Grandpa was an early 20th century comic strip and its cartoonist was Carl E. Schultze. In the political cartoon, Foxy Grandpa is seated next to a caveman wielding a stone hammer.
The caveman appears to break his dish with a stone tool. The character appeared in Our Antediluvian Ancestors by Frederick Burr Opper.
Gloomy Gus was a character in Opper's Happy Hooligan. In the political cartoon, he is dressed in ragged clothing and appears to stuff his pockets with the silverware and a bottle of champagne.
The dinosaur character appeared in Our Antediluvian Ancestors by Frederick Burr Opper. In the political cartoon, he is eating a portrait of Theodore Roosevelt.
